loans.name: Los Cedrales Group

texts.es:
La señora Crisolina R., ex integrante de este grupo, domiciliada en Acaray de Minga Guazú, contactó con sus vecinas y amigas para formar el comité en la zona, ya que muchas de ellas tienen emprendimientos que necesitan ser apoyados.
El nombre que han puesto al comité es  “Los Cedrales”, en homenaje al barrio de la mayoría de ellas.  Están  en el Quinto Ciclo, con 12  integrantes. Es un grupo que se destaca  por ser muy unido, solidario  y responsable. Las integrantes tienen actividades diferentes. 
Las mismas poseen un gran espíritu emprendedor, ya que están al día con las cuotas, realizan actividades de recaudación de fondos para terminar esta etapa con muy buen cumplimiento con la institución. 
Una de las integrantes es la señora  Norma quien  se dedica a la atención de un salón de belleza que posee en su casa. 
Ella es una mujer muy sacrificada que trabajo desde muy joven. 
Ella tiene su clientela formada y sus clientas recurren frecuentemente hasta su salón por su buena atención. 
Solicita el préstamo para la compra de productos que utiliza en su peluquería, como cremas de enjuagues, shampoo, aceites y otros.
texts.en:
Sra. Crisolina R., a former member [of another group], lives in Acaray de Minga Guazu.  She organized a local committee after inviting friends and neighbors from the area to join, many of whom have small businesses that need support.  The group is called "Los Cedrales" after the neighborhood in which most of them live.  The group is starting its fifth round of funding with 12 members.  
The group is notable for being united, cohesive and responsible in their dealings with one another.  The members operate various businesses.  They share an entrepreneurial spirit and manage their loans wisely because they want to repay it on time and remain in good stead with the bank.  
One of the members is Sra. Norma who owns a beauty salon that she operates from her house.  She has worked since she was very young and has had to sacrifice a lot.  She now has a good customer base and her customers come back to her again and again.  She is applying for a loan to buy supplies for the salon: creams, shampoo, oils, etc.

loans.use: Buy supplies for beauty salon business.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy W. W. is thirty-six years old, married and has three children. Her business is located at Changamwe estate in Mombasa, Kenya. Mombasa is the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many tourist attraction sites, not forgetting the Indian ocean white beaches.

She has been selling vegetables, coconuts and potatoes for the last two years and she serves the local people. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is the high perishability of some of her items like tomatoes. However, she works very hard from early morning to late evening to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more vegetables, coconuts and potatoes to expand her business and meet the demands of her customers. She hopes to be a wholesaler in future. She describes herself as patient, aggressive and goal oriented.

loans.use: To buy vegetables, coconuts and potatoes.

loans.name: Jannette's Group

texts.en:
Jannette B. is from the village of Gosi Sur. She is 47 years old and the group leader of a four-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Jannette B.'s Group.

Jannette is married. To make a living, she owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty-five years and earns approximately $94 a month for these activities.

In 2010, she joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand her product offering.

Jannette is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 2nd loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business as savings for future emergencies. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ronald

texts.es:
Ronald Álvarez es un conocido profesor de música de la trinchera de Alajuela. 
Además de eso Ronald tiene su propio negocio, hace mucho tiempo inicio con una pequeña buseta, transportando estudiantes de la comunidad. Hoy ya tiene tres busetas, sin embargo una de ellas necesita una reparación total del motor. Es por eso que necesita un préstamo de ¢500 000 (quinientos mil colones)  para pagar el arreglo, y poder seguir sirviendo a la comunidad.
El espera que manteniendo el negocio gracias al préstamo podrá más adelante comprarse otra Buseta.
El es socio de la Empresa Comunal de Mujeres al Éxito de la Trinchera de Pital, una de las 100 organizaciones socias de EDESA en Costa Rica.
texts.en:
Ronald Álvarez is a well-known music teacher in the community of Alajuela. In addition, Ronald has his own business that he started a long time ago using a small minibus for transporting students in the community. Now he has three minibuses, but one of the vehicles needs an engine overhaul. For this reason he needs a loan of 500,000 CRC to pay for the repairs so that he can continue serving the community.

Ronald expects to maintain his business with the loan so that he can later buy another minibus. He is a member of the Communal Enterprise of Successful Women in Trinchera de Pital, one of the 100 member organizations that make up EDESA in Costa Rica.

loans.use: Minibus repairs

loans.name: Sop Serigne Fallou Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité SOP SERIGNE FALLOU est créé le 03 décembre 2009. Il est composé de 36 femmes qui habitent la même localité. Elles ont formé leur groupe par voisinage et par affinité. Leurs activités dominantes sont le petit commerce, l'agriculture et la transformation.

Madame FATOU ABDOU N. debout à droite sur la photo, habillée en vert est la responsable du groupe. Elle est âgée 23 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 04 enfants. Elle a aussi la charge de sa petit sœur et la nièce de son mari

Elle fait de l'embouche ovine. Et parallèlement elle vend des chaussures et des fruits de saison. 

Son objectif est de participer à l'amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille, subvenir à ses besoins et constituer une bonne épargne.
texts.en:
The solidarity group Sop Serigne Fallou was created on December 3, 2009. It is composed of 36 women, all living in the same neighborhood and knowing each other because they are neighbors and friends. Most of them run small stores, or are active in agriculture or processing.

Mrs Fatou Abdou N., standing to the right in the picture and wearing a green dress, chairs the group. She is 23 years old, married and the mother of four children. In addition, she cares for her younger sister and her husband's niece. She breeds sheep. At the same time, she sells footwear and seasonal fruit. Her objective is to contribute to improved living conditions for her family, provide for her needs and save an appreciable amount of money.

loans.use: To buy two sheep

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more clothes, wheat flour and cooking oil

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase fertilizers for his plantation

loans.name: Massavi

texts.fr:
Madame Massavi gère comme activité génératrice de revenus, la vente de matériaux de constructions. Elle a commencé depuis 2008 et s’approvisionne au Ghana à Accra. Ensuite elle revend les matériaux dans le quartier Tokoin wuiti en face de CEG côté sud. Son stock de marchandises est en baisse, elle cherche à se réapprovisionner, raison pour laquelle elle sollicite un crédit.
Elle est mariée à un directeur de société et mère de 2 enfants, avec son commerce elle participe aux dépenses de sa famille.
texts.en:
Mrs. Massavi manages as an income generating business, the selling of construction materials. She has been in business since 2008 and purchases her inventory in Accra, Ghana. She then sells the materials in the Tokoin wuiti neighborhood in front of the CEG on the south side. Her inventory is low so she is asking for a loan in order to purchase more inventory.
She is married to the manager of a company and has two children. Her business helps pay the family expenses.

loans.use: to purchase construction materials

loans.name: Ignace

texts.en:
Ignace is 53 years old and is married with three children who are between 15 and 10 years old. He owns a shop selling bananas. He has owned this shop for about five years and the hours of this business are from 6am until 5pm every day. He employs two people to help him.

Ignace has now requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase a large quantity of bananas to sell. He hopes that through those additional goods he will earn more profits and these profits will allow him to keep reinvesting and start saving for a better future.

loans.use: To purchase a larger quantity of bananas.

loans.name: Banaba Group

texts.en:
Liza S. is from the village of Biasong, Lopez Jaena, Mis. Occ.. She is 34 years old. Liza is the leader of a three-member group loan offered by GDMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Liza is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Liza makes and sells food and drinks for passenger in the bus terminal. Liza has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 1,400 PHP a month.

In 2011, Liza joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Liza is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase plastic wares to be used for her business. This will be the first loan taken out by Liza from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase plastic wares to be used for her business

loans.name: Diana Oliva

texts.es:
La Señora. Diana R. es socia del banco comunal 14 de Agosto, vive en la comunidad de Zhidmad  donde se puede disfrutar de hermosos paisajes, su gente se dedica a la cría de animales y a la agricultura, mucha de su población sale diariamente a laborar en la ciudad y muchos también han migrado en busca de un mejor futuro para sus familias.

La Señora. Diana tiene 29 años, es casada y tiene 2 hijos de 9 y 6 años de edad que  estudian en una escuelita de la localidad. Su esposo es un maestro en la rama de la construcción, no tienen casa propia por lo que viven en la casa de sus padres con quienes comparten los gastos del hogar.

Doña Diana tiene en un bazar en el que trabaja de domingo a domingo desde las 7 de la mañana hasta las 8 de la noche. Esta actividad le da tiempo para cuidar de sus hijos y familia.
 
Es socia del banco comunal hace 3 años y su nuevo crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de artículos de bazar.
 
Su meta es crecer en su negocio.
texts.en:
Diana R. is a member of the communal bank “14 de Agosto” (August 14th).  She lives in the Zhidmad community where one can enjoy the beautiful countryside where the people work raising animals and in agriculture.  Much of the population goes daily to the city to work and many have also left to look for a better future for their families. 

Diana is 29-years-old and is married with two children who are nine and six-years-old and who study in a little school in their area.  Her husband works in construction.  They do not have their own house because they live in his parent’s house with whom they share the expenses of the house.

Diana has a stationery shop where she works Sunday to Sunday from seven in the morning to eight at night.  This gives her time to care for her children and family.

She has been a member of the communal bank for three years and her new loan will be invested in items for the stationery shop.  

Her goal is to grow her business.

loans.use: to buy items for a stationery shop.

loans.name: María Laura

texts.es:
La Señora. María es socia del banco comunal Santa Ana, vive en la parroquia de  Santa Ana, esta parroquia es de clima frió, tiene una hermosa vista de la ciudad de Cuenca y de la naturaleza, su gente se dedica a la cría de animales y a la agricultura, muchos laboran en la ciudad ejerciendo varias actividades.

La Señora María tiene 59 años, es casada y tienen 3 hijos, dos mayores de edad que son  casados e independientes, su último hijo es soltero y trabaja para sus gastos. Su esposo labora como guardia de seguridad, con el trabajo conyugal han logrado construir su casa propia.

Doña María se dedica a los quehaceres de su hogar en donde aprovecha su tiempo para criar animales como: gallinas, cerdos y vacas. Sus animales los vende en su propia comunidad.
 
Es una socia fundadora del banco comunal y le gusta ya que tiene muy buenas amigas en la banca. El dinero de su crédito lo va  a invertir en la compra de ganado.
 
Su meta es tener mas animales para la cría.
texts.en:
Maria is a member of the communal bank Santa Ana. She lives in the community of Santa Ana. It is a cold climate district and it has a beautiful view of the city of Cuenca and the natural surroundings. The population is made up of livestock farmers and agriculturists. Many work in the city in various business activities.

She is 59 years old, married, and she has 3 children, two of whom are grown, married, and independent. Her youngest child is single and works to cover his expenses. Her husband works as a security guard. With their combined work they have managed to build a house of their own. 

She takes care of the household obligations and she takes advantage of her time to raise livestock, such as: poultry, pigs, and cows. Her livestock are sold in her own community. 

She is a founding member of the communal bank and she enjoys having many good friends in the bank. The funds from her loan will be invested in the purchase of cattle.

Her goal is to have more livestock to raise.

loans.use: to purchase cattle.

loans.name: Mao

texts.en: Mao has been living in the Siem Reap Province from when she was young until the present time. She is a 47-year-old woman who sells one kind of Khmer cake. She always has many customers who come to buy her tasty cake. Usually Mao generates around $5 profit a day to meet the needs of her family. She is a single woman because she was divorced from her husband a few years ago. She has three children, one works in the construction field as a domestic construction worker, another is selling Khmer cake, and the other one is an office staff member for a private company. Mao has decided to ask for a loan of $1000 to buy a new motorbike for her child to commute to their workplace.

loans.use: to buy a new motorbike for her child to commute to their workplace.

loans.name: Isenzesihle Group

texts.en:
Sindisiwe is 54 years old and married with eight children between the ages of 32 and 40. She takes care of her two grandchildren and they both attend school. She runs a retail business in Kwa Zulu Natal of Empangeni in South Africa. In the photo, she is pictured raising her hand. 
 
She has been in business for six years selling traditional mates and bananas at her home. She also receives income from a government child support grant.  Sindisiwe requested this loan through WDB and Kiva to buy flowers and vegetables to increase her stock.  She says the main challenge she faces in her business is her bananas because she cannot keep them for more than a week. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her improve her life and her family. In the future, she would like to grow her business.

loans.use: To buy flowers and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Prince 1 Group

texts.fr: Le groupe PRINCE 1 est composé de trois personnes qui habitent la même localité. C'est la première fois que ce groupe sollicite l'aide financier de ALIDé, afin d'élever le niveau de leur activité. La représentante du groupe du nom de Gisèle est celle qui a la main levée sur la photo. Gisèle a 46 ans et vit au Bénin. Gisèle est mariée à un menuisier du nom de Joseph. Le couple à trois enfants tous scolarisés, et ne vivant plus avec eux. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de son mari, Gisèle mène comme activité depuis trente ans la vente du maïs et de la farine de manioc. A côté de cette activité Gisèle vend des produits divers. Gisèle s’approvisionne dans l’un des plus grands marchés du Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et pour accroître son chiffre d’affaires et son revenu, Gisèle sollicite ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe PRINCE 1, un premier crédit.
texts.en: The PRINCE 1 group is composed of three people who live in the same area.  This is the first time that this group has asked for financial aid from ALIDé, so as to grow their businesses.  Gisèle, the group’s representative, is the one with her hand raised in the photo.  Gisèle is 46 years old and lives in Benin.  She is married to Joseph, a carpenter.  The couple has three children who have all been to school and no longer live with them.  To provide for her needs and those of her husband, Gisèle has operated a business selling corn and manioc flour for thirty years.  In addition to this business, Gisèle sells various products.  Gisèle gets her supplies in one of Benin’s largest markets.   Gisèle is asking for a first loan, together with the other members of the PRINCE 1 group, with the goals of satisfying her customers and expanding her sales and income.

loans.use: To buy bags of corn and manioc flour.

loans.name: Yusufu

texts.en:
Yusufu is a divorced man with three children, all of whom attend school. He lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food and rent.

For the past three years, Yusufu has operated a spare parts business, selling from his shop to his neighbors and passersby. His major challenge in the business is seasonality. During the rainy season, it becomes difficult to operate a motorcycle business. Yusufu dreams of owning a public transport vehicle in the future. 

Yusufu plans to use this KES 20,000 loan to purchase motorcycle spare parts to repair his motorcycle. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: To purchase motorcycle spare parts to repair his motorcycle.

loans.name: Alex

texts.en:
Alex is married with four children. His rice field was inherited from his parents, and he has been cultivating the farm for twenty years now. Great improvements in his farm will mean a lot to his family, especially his children for whom he wants a comfortable life.

Last harvest, Alex generated 15,000 PHP net income from his yield. This was low when compared to his family’s daily expenditures, so he decided to apply for a loan that would help him improve his yield next harvest.

Alex’s loan will be used to purchase hybrid seed, fertilizers and insecticides to use in his rice field to ensure a better yield. For his part, he is determined to utilize the loan wisely and see to it that his farm is doing great.

Alex said he will do his best to improve his farming not just for a prosperous life, but also to pay tribute to his parents for entrusting him with the farm for which they have worked many long years.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed, fertilizers and insecticides to use in his rice field.

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.es:
La Sra. Yolanda pertenece al Banco Comunal “Los Eucaliptos”, del Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia y Departamento de San Martín. Es Conviviente, tiene 48 años y tiene 01 hija de 17 años de edad, estudiante de nivel superior en la carrera de Administración de Empresas. Desde hace 21 años es muy aficionada al negocio, inicialmente se dedicaba a la venta de cosméticos, la cual no fue rentable debido a que sus clientes no le cancelaban sus productos a tiempo. Inicia su pequeño negocio de venta de abarrotes y productos de primera necesidad  con un capital de S/300.00 nuevos soles; 
Ahora amplió su negocio, brinda el servicio de recargas de celulares, ventas de tarjetas telefónicas, incrementó sus productos e insumos haciéndose muy rápidamente de muy buena clientela por su carisma y buena atención.
Con este préstamo de S/. 3000.00 surtirá y comprará productos para su negocio como:  cajas de jabones ,cajas de leche, sacos de azúcar y arroz, paquetes de fideos, jabas de huevos así como insumos para el aseo personal y limpieza del hogar, gaseosas en paquetes, tarjetas telefónicas, recarga de celulares y otros.
La Sra. Yolanda es una mujer emprendedora, su sueño es contar con un Mini Market que le permita generar más ganancias. Está muy agradecida con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos por ayudar a mujeres como ella a realizar sus sueños.
texts.en:
Yolanda belongs to the Los Eucaliptos Communal Bank, in the Tarapoto District of the Province and Department of San Martín. She lives with her partner, is 48 years old, and has one 17 year old daughter, who studies Business Administration at the advanced level. 

For the past 21 years she has been very keen with business. Initially she sold cosmetics, which was not profitable given that her clients wouldn't pay off their purchases on time. She began her small groceries and basic necessities business with S/300.00 and has now expanded her business to offer cell phone card reloads and phone cards. She increased her stock and merchandise, attracting very good customers very quickly because of her carisma and good customer service. 

With this loan of S/3000.00, she will purchase and stock products for her business such as: soap, milk cartons, sacks of sugar and rice, noodle packets, and egg cartons as well as personal hygiene and cleaning products, packs of sodas, phone cards, and more. 

Yolanda is a very enterprising woman and her dream is to have a Mini Market that would allow her to realize greater profits. She is very grateful to the Movimiento Manuela Ramos for helping women like her to see their dreams come true.

loans.use: to stock merchandise and cell phone cards.

loans.name: Rayya

texts.en: Rayya is a 52-year-old woman. She is married and has 10 sons and 8 daughters. Her husband is sometimes employed and Rayya has her own project, which is selling fruits and vegetables, So Rayya's work is mainly the only source of income for the family. Rayya needs to increase her sales in the feast season by purchasing big amounts of fruits and vegetables to sell and increase her income, especially now that the feast is around the corner. Rayya has an amount of money that isn't enough to pay, so she needs to take a loan of $1,000 from FATEN. When Rayya gets the FATEN loan, which is repaid on a monthly basis, she will be able to purchase more fruits and vegetables and increase her income so her family will have better life conditions. Rayya is photographed in the place where she is selling fruits and vegetables.

loans.use: To purchase fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita is 48 years old and married with five children.  With one child in school, Anita works very hard to provide for her children.

Anita runs a variety store in the Philippines and has requested a 29,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy items to sell such as shampoo, groceries, etc.

She has been in this business for twenty years and sells a variety of items such as spices, detergent bars, sardines, oil, etc. 

In the future Anita would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy items to sell in her variety store.

loans.name: Oscar

texts.en:
Oscar is 45 years old and lives in the Philippines. He is married and has three children.
 
Oscar has a shop that sells a variety of dried fish. He has had this business for two years. 

He requested a loan for PHP 4,000 to buy dried fish for resale. Oscar has been a member of HSPFI since 2009. In the future, Oscar hopes to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy dried fish to resell.

loans.name: Maribel

texts.en:
Maribel is 27 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 4 children. 

Maribel has a shop that sells canned goods, snacks and beverages. She has had this business for 2 years. She requested a loan for 11,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages.

Maribel has been a member of HSPFI since 2010. In the future, Maribel hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages.

loans.name: Celia

texts.en:
Celia is 50 years old and lives in Bacolod; Ozamiz City. She is married with five adult children. 

Celia owns a motorcycle and uses it as her business, operating it within Ozamiz City. She earns approximately 3000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) each month doing this type of work. She has a requested a loan of 10,000 PHP to purchase equipment for her motorcycle. 

Celia has been a member of PMPC for one year. In the future, Celia hopes that she will not encounter failure in her business and can purchase a lot of motorcycles within five years.

loans.use: to purchase equipment for her motorcycle

loans.name: Juana

texts.es: Los hijos d ela socia tienen 24, 20, 17, 15 años de edad, la socia se dedica  avarias actividades como la compra y venta de ropa para damas y caballeros, la crianza de animales como pollos, cuyes, ovejas y ahora plásticos para la epoca de lluvias, la socia desea invertir el credito en la compra de plastico al por mayor, la socia comprara plástico para la venta en su stand en la feria del pueblo, ella trae al por mayor de Juliaca y los vende por metros, la socia desearía en poco tiempo comprar un terreno para cultivar y vender la producción, la socia con los ingresos que generan sus ventas invierte en los estudios de sus hijos. La socia soliciate el prestamo para invertir en la compra de plásticos al por mayor.
texts.en: The member’s children are 24, 20, 17 and 15 years old.  She carries out a variety of activities like buying and selling clothes for women and men, raising animals like chickens, guinea pigs and sheep and now plastic sheeting for the rainy season.  She wants to use the loan to buy plastic at wholesale.  She will buy plastic to resell in her market stand in town.  She buys it at wholesale in Juliaca and then sells it by the meter.  She’d like to be able to buy a piece of farmland to cultivate shortly and sell her crops.  She invests income generated from her sales into her children’s education.  She is asking for the loan to buy plastic sheeting at wholesale.

loans.use: to buy plastics at wholesale.

loans.name: Myrna Criado's Group

texts.en:
Myrna is married with three adult-aged children. She is 64 years old and lives in Carmen Annex, Ozamis City.

Myrna sells fertilized duck eggs (balut) to earn a living and has had this business for four years. Each month, she earns PHP 3,000 doing this type of work. She has requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to purchase more duck eggs for her balut business. 

Myrna has been a member of PMPC for two years. In the future, Myrna hopes to save money for business expansion. 

Mryna is the leader of a four-person group.  Although they borrow as a group, each member of the group has their own business.

loans.use: to purchase more duck eggs.

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is a hardworking businessman aged 39. He is married and blessed with four children who are in school. For the last three years, he has been selling clothes to support his family. In the next five years, he plans to manage a wholesale business. 

He has requested a loan of 10,000 Kenya shillings to add stock of clothes for resale. Charles dreams of becoming more financially stable in the future. Thanks to Faulu Kenya, he has been able to save part of his income.

loans.use: To add stock of clothes.

loans.name: Savath

texts.en:
Savath and her husband are farmers and she is also a weaver. She is asking for a loan in the mount of $400 to purchase seed, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain her farm. 

Savath and her husband have been married since 1990 and have 3 sons and 1 daughter. One is married, two are in school and another one is a weaver. They live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

In the photo, Savath is at home, not at the farm.

loans.use: to buy seed, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain her farm.

loans.name: Esnas

texts.en: Esnas is taking another Kiva loan of KES 30,000 to improve her beauty salon business. With the loan she wants to repair a hair-drying machine. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business. Esnas dreams of expanding her boutique shop to meet her customers' needs in the future.

loans.use: to repair a hair-drying machine.

loans.name: Toroitich

texts.en:
Toroitich is a 36-year-old man who is married to Purity, and they have three children who are 13, 10 and 6 years old. He is a livestock trader and his wife practices farming on their family farm. He has been in the livestock farming business for the last 4 years with an income of about Kenya shillings 10,000 every month. His wife also contributes to the family’s income with around 5,000 shillings every month.

This is his first loan with KADET LTD, and he would like to buy more cows and goats for raising and selling at a later date. He anticipates an increase in profits which he will plow back into the livestock business. 

He dreams of becoming a very rich person in future.

loans.use: To buy more cows and goats for resale at a later date.

loans.name: Sukanti

texts.en:
Sukanti is 47 years old woman. She lives with her husband and two children in a small colony of Jeypore city of Koraput district, Odisha. 

She owns a grocery shop near to her house where she sells basic household items such as sugar, biscuits, edible oil, flour, rice, chocolates, spices, packaged food, etc. She also sells vegetables and earns 7,000 to 8,000 INR per month. Her current income is not sufficient for her family’s expenses, as her two children are in school, and her family lives in a city.

Sukanti has requested a loan of 35,000 INR to purchase a big fridge to keep perishable goods and also add more products in her grocery store. 

She hopes to do well in her business. She is grateful to the Kiva lenders for this support.

loans.use: to purchase a big fridge to keep perishable goods and add more products in his grocery store.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase kerosene for sale.

loans.name: Uyeh

texts.en:
Uyeh feel very happy to become a member of MBK. She has requested her second loan of $100 from MBK. The raised loan will be used for the small kiosk and to help her husband to buy fertilizers for his farm. In a day, Uyeh typically earns IDR 230,000 with a profit of IDR 30,000

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Frely Pakan, Kiva Volunteer.

loans.use: Buy more supplies for her kiosk

loans.name: Monicah

texts.en:
Monicah W. K. is a married woman, age 25. She has two kids of her own and another one whom she has to take care of. Monicah did a course in pharmacy but due to the recent competition in that field, she was unable to secure a job. She was so stressed out that her mother, having sufficient experience in poultry farming, advised her on starting the same business.

Monicah did quite well and her business really picked up. She however does not have enough money to expand the business and now she is requesting a loan of US$ 600. She will use US$ 300 to buy more poultry, US$120 to prepare a place to keep the chickens, and US$ 180 to buy poultry feed. She is certain that this will work well for her.

loans.use: purchase poultry and poultry feed

loans.name: Fd

texts.en: test here

loans.use: sdfsd

loans.name: Fanolua

texts.en:
Fanolua M. is from Faleasiu, a mother of two sons, unemployed but running a small cattle farm with her husband. Fanolua M. is the secretary for their community, and a very active member in the program. She has been in business for 4 years now and is still going strong because she believes that there is a future in her business.

Her business is their only source of income to support her children’s schooling needs. Her eldest son will be graduating from University this year, and she is very looking forward to celebrating it. This is why she’s now requesting a $900 loan to do maintenance on her house and to pay for her son’s school fees. Fanolua aims to expand her business in the near future when both her sons successfully graduate from school.

loans.use: Loan will be used to purchase materials for home improvement and to pay for her son’s school fees.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her vegetable-selling business

loans.name: Janeth

texts.en:
Janeth is a single woman, age 28, who cares for two of her sister’s children, Gladness, 13, and Goodluck, 9. In 2005 she established a business raising and selling chickens. She would like to expand her business and increase her profit in order to support her family. She requires a loan of US $275 to purchase more chicks to add to her growing brood!

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus termed not creditworthy by financial institutions, as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipments from the said client, extending a loan to her and then leases beck the same equipment – a process called sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase additional chicks to raise for sale.

loans.name: Dina

texts.es:
Dina is very happy to see that her business has improved this past year. Two years ago, she decided to purchase a copy machine and offer photocopy services in her own home to the students in her city. She also sells office supplies following her customers’ suggestions. Because of Dina’s efforts, not only is her family happy, but also her neighbors now that they have found a convenient place to buy their much-needed supplies. She is requesting this loan because she would like to expand her business space. Let’s make this hard-working mother’s dream possible so that she can keep helping other families.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Dina, está muy contenta porque ha visto que su negocio ha mejorado en este último año; debido a que hace dos años decidió instalar en su propia casa una fotocopiadora para brindar sus servicios a la comunidad estudiantil de su ciudad, además de este servicio por recomendaciones decidió surtirla con útiles de escritorio. Con esta decisión no sólo esta contenta la familia de Dina sino también sus vecinos debido a que han hallado un cómodo lugar para realizar las compras más urgentes.Ella desea implementar aún más su pequeño establecimiento y por esa razón solicita un préstamo.Posibilitemos su petición para que esta trabajadora madre siga ayudando a más familias.

loans.use: Expansion of business space

loans.name: Sri

texts.id:
With a profit of 200,000 Rupiah per week, Sri J. is able to meet the day to day needs of life. By decorating regular sandals, she is able to sell them for a profit of 5,000 Rupiah. Her daily expenses are 20,000 Rupiah. In addition to her daily living costs, she must pay rent for her house. Because she lives alone, she feels she can focus more completely on growing her business.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Courtenay Teska Race, Kiva Volunteer.

Dengan keuntungan per minggu Rp 200.000,00, Sri memenuhi kebutuhan hidupnya. Per pasang sandal rata – rata dia mengambil keuntungan Rp 5.000,00. Per hari dia mengeluarkan Rp 20.000,00 untuk biaya hidup. Selain itu dia harus mengeluarkan biaya sewa untuk kontrak rumahnya. Karena hidup sendiri dia merasa lebih bisa fokus terhadap perkembangan usahanya ini.

loans.use: for business captiol

loans.name: José Arturo

texts.es:
José Arturo studied computer sciences, learning how to repair computers. After finishing his studies, he started working at a private company; however, his income was not sufficient for him to be independent. He no longer wanted to be a burden on his parents. José Arturo is currently married, which is why he is so enthusiastic about making his business grow, hoping to one day set it up in a business space.

Nevertheless, what José needs to do first is keep his customers and offer them first-rate service. For this reason, he is requesting a loan of $675.00 USD, which he is willing to repay in 6 monthly installments, in order to purchase tools and computer parts so that he can offer his customers better services and keep them coming back for more. With your help, José will be able to save enough money so that his children will not lack anything they need.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

José Arturo, estudió una carrera de sistemas, en dónde aprendió a reparar problemas a las computadoras. Después de terminar su carrera comenzó a trabajar en una empresa. Sin embargo lo que ganaba no era suficiente para poder ser independiente. Puesto que José deseaba ya no ser una carga para sus padres. Actualmente José Arturo ya se encuentra casado y es por eso que tiene más entusiasmo para poder crecer su negocio y algún día estabilizarlo con un local.

Sin embargo lo primero que tiene que hacer José, es conservar a sus clientes y ofrecerles un servicio de primera. Es por eso que está solicitando un crédito de US $675 que está dispuesto a pagarlos en un plazo de 6 meses y con este dinero José podrá comprar sus herramientas y refacciones para poder brindarle un mejor servicio a sus clientes y que estos regresen a su empresa. Con tu ayuda José podrá hacer un ahorro para que no le falte nada a los hijos que desea tener.

loans.use: Purchase of tools

loans.name: Hilario

texts.es:
Since leaving his hometown of Cuzco with his beloved parents as a teenager to live in the city of Juliaca, Hilario and his parents had been engaged in various activities to support themselves financially. But despite their great efforts their income continued to be inadequate. Using their initiative, they decided to begin making clothes hangers. Initially they did not put much emphasis on this work because it did not generate sufficient income. But gradually, as they decided to make the hangers in larger quantities and distribute them wholesale, the situation improved.

Hilario has his own family now and is the father of two small children, whom he adores and are his motivation. That is why this enterprising father plans to produce a variety of clothes hangers in different sizes and models. With your important contribution, his plans would be realized.

Translated from Spanish by MuseAndThinker, Kiva Volunteer

Desde adolescente Hilario y sus queridos padres decidieron salir de su ciudad natal, Cuzco, para radicar en la ciudad de Juliaca, desde que viven en dicha ciudad se han dedicado a diversas actividades para cubrir sus gastos familiares pero aún con mucho esfuerzo seguía siendo insuficiente, es así que con mucha creatividad y habilidad han ido fabricando colgadores para ropas, en un principio no le dieron mucha importancia a esta labor porque no les generaba ingresos económicos sustanciales pero poco a poco conforme fabricaban en mayores cantidades y los distribuían al por mayor las cosas fueron cambiando.Actualmente Hilario ya formó su propia familia y es padre de 2 pequeños niños, quienes son su mayor adoración y el motivo de su esfuerzo, es por ello que este emprendedor padre tiene pensado seguir fabricando variedad de colgadores y en diversos modelos y tamaños.Con tu importante aporte obtendrá concretar sus planes

loans.use: Capital injection to purchase larger quantities of raw materials for making finished products

loans.name: Sichana's Mtegemee Mola Group

texts.en:
Sichana, age 31, is a single mother with two children, ages 16 and 12. Three years ago, Sichana began her business of selling snacks, such as wheat porridge and breads, in order to make a living. She works from 7am to 3pm daily and is able to make a monthly profit of about $25.

Sichana hopes for a loan to purchase more food items for to make more snacks. She will share this loan with her subgroup, whose members belong to group Mtegemee Mola. These members guarantee one another to pay back loans.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her snacks shop

loans.name: Ilhomjon

texts.en: J. Ilhomjon was born in 1976 in the B.Gafurov region of Tajikistan. He is married and has 2 children. Mr. J. Ilhomjon has a good reputation. He is a very hard working man and a good family man. Mr. J. Ilhomjon has been interested in photography since his early years. He took special courses and learned the specified skills. Now Mr. J. Ilhomjon is a professional photographer and has a photography studio. Mr. J. Ilhomjon applies to KIVA with the request of a business support loan for 8 months so that he can purchase new equipment.

loans.use: To purchase new equipment

loans.name: Hai Seminary Merikolong 2044-4 Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Fibi K.. She currently sells posho and beans and is requesting a loan to open up a shop. Fibi is 35 years old and is married to a peasant. She has five children, ranging from age 6 to 16, all of whom go to school. Each week, Fibi makes approximately 100 Sudanese pounds in profit and hopes to open up a shop with the extra capital from her loan.

Fibi is joined in her small group by MaK. O., Baronica K., Voulale E., and Lona J.. MaK. sells bread and wants to buy an oven. Baronica sells vegetables and wants a loan to pay school fees. Voulale E. sells charcoal and wants to expand the business. Lona sells bread and is requesting a loan to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To open up a shop.

loans.name: Jemaida's Kambaya Group

texts.en:
Jemaida is a 26-year-old, married woman with one 2-year-old child. She owns and operates a small grocery store, which she started in 2008. Every day, she works extremely hard from 7 am to 4 pm at her business and, in doing so, she can earn a monthly profit of approximately $20 from her sales.

Jemaida now requests a loan in order to buy more grocery items for her business. Notably, she will share the loan proceeds with her subgroup member, Hadija, who has her own business selling charcoal.

loans.use: To improve and expand her business by purchasing additional groceries

loans.name: Bisi

texts.en: Bisi O. lives in Ajamgbadi, Lagos State, Nigeria. She is 41 years old and married with six children. Bisi runs a business selling firewood and charcoal, mostly to her neighbors.  Bisi is requesting a loan in the amount of $700 USD to buy more firewood and charcoal to sell. She extends her thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more firewood and charcoal to sell

loans.name: Šerifa

texts.en: ŠErifa P. is 38 years old and comes from Visoko, a litlle town near Sarajevo. She is married and has three children. Her husband has a regular job and ŠErifa does not. But, ŠErifa is busy collecting and selecting secondary raw materials every day. Her children are helping her in her daily work. ŠErifa`s husband does the same when he is not at his job. Once a week they bring the materials to a collection point. From time to time they find somebody who has more reserves of secondary raw materials and they buy them. They need some cash to be able to buy them whenever they have the chance. Erifa will take a loan from WWI which amounts to 1500 KM to buy materials for reselling. This is their way to make some progress in their lives.

loans.use: To buy secondary row materials

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose A. sells food supplies including frozen fish. She buys the fresh fish from the fishermen and then keeps them in her cold store for her customers at Kotokoraba in Cape Coast to come and buy. Rose has received a junior high education. She is married and has 3 children. Her husband is a mason. Rose has been selling frozen fish since 1993. She is responsible for helping her husband pay for school fees and other family expenses. Her loan will be used to increase the quantity of fish she sells to meet the increase in demand and also to buy food supplies for resale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to expand her capital base to increase her income to enable her to meet the basic needs of her family.

loans.use: Her loan will be used to increase the quantity of fish she sells to meet the increase in demand and also to buy food supplies for resale.

loans.name: Adham

texts.en:
Adham is a 38-year-old man who lives in Saida, southern Lebanon, with his wife and their two children. Adham has a small restaurant where he sells falafel and “shawarma” (chicken) sandwiches. He has been in this business for 20 years. He requested a loan of 700 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to pay the school tuition fees for his children.

Adham has a good reputation and has a lot of clients. In the future, he plans to expand his business and maybe diversify his choice of food. This is the third cycle for Adham in a micro-credit field.

loans.use: Adham needs the loan to pay the school tuition fees for his children

loans.name: Noor Muhammad

texts.en:
Noor Muhammad B. is 27 and the father of four children and he lives in Behsood Beland Ghar Jalalabad. He works in agriculture and he has been involved in this field for more than 10 years. He used to be able to support his family well but things are not very good. He is faced with lots of economic difficulties in his family, so he wants to expand his business.

He needs money to expand his business to help his family. He wants to take out an individual loan to complete his seed stock and ready all his land for cultivation, to work hard and make a better income to support his family.

He is happy about this loan. He would like to thank Kiva and the lenders that make this opportunity possible in this poor country where people are faced with lots of problems. He hopes to be successful in his business in the future.

loans.use: buying seeds and preparing his land

loans.name: Olga

texts.en:
Olga is single. She is an entrepreneur from Bolekhiv. Olga sells groceries in one of the local markets. She started this business with the help of her friend four years ago. She has gained a good clientele since she started working. Currently, she already has about 4,000 Grivnas in gross income. Her inventory amounts to 25,000 Grivnas.

Olga is requesting 5000 Grivnas as a loan to purchase fruit, fish, and other products for her small kiosk. She is hoping to see her business expand and grow consistently. Olga has a cheerful personality which is always a positive factor in work with customers. She is willing to work really hard to see her business flourish in the future.

loans.use: purchase food inventory

loans.name: Marjorie

texts.en:
Marjorie C. is 40 years old and has three children. Her husband grows rice to support their two children who are still studying. The cost of sending their children to school is painful in their budget. So they need to work very hard to meet all the family's needs.

In 1994, Marjorie started selling her farm produce in her store. From the small amount of capital that she had saved up, she added merchandise. Her customers are people in their neighborhood. Her rice made her earn more profit in her store. This is because rice is a much needed commodity; everybody buys rice.

She is requesting a loan from CEVI of Php 10,000. She will use the loan to buy groceries and feed for pig owners in their hometown. She is also considering looking for some other possible areas to augment their income.

Marjorie is happy to be taking advantage of credit assistance, training, and insurance coverage that CEVI provides to all its clients.

loans.use: Purchase of groceries for her store and fertilizer for her farm

loans.name: Kafayati

texts.en: Kafayati is 37 years old and married with 2 children. She sells sarongs at Bola Ige Market in Ibadan, Oyo state, Nigeria. She requests a loan of N50000 to purchase a greater variety of sarongs to sell. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase a greater variety of sarongs to sell

loans.name: Anna

texts.en:
Anna O. is 50 years old. She is married and has given birth to nine children, three girls and six boys. Six of them are currently in school: senior high, junior high and primary schools. The rest are running their own businesses and living independently. Her husband works with a mining company in their community. She lives with her husband and children in a family house in a small farming community called Hweakwae in the Eastern Region of Ghana. The major occupation of the dwellers in this community is farming. The land is rich in nutrients and as a result, many inhabitants combine trading and farming activities. 
Anna is into the palm oil production business. She says she procures palm fruits from the local farmers to prepare the oil. She distributes to customers who come to buy in bulk and retail. Anna wants a loan to procure palm fruits in bulk so that she can produce the oil in bulk and distribute to her increasing number of customers. It is her dream to help her husband give their children the best education.

loans.use: To procure palm nuts in bulk

loans.name: Rosa Amelia

texts.es: la sra Rosa Gutierrz es una persona que se dedica al alquiler de apartamentos desde hace mucho tiempo, con este trabajo pudo salir adelante ella y su hija ya que es viuda, ella se levanta muy temprano para asear los apartamentos y el solar a la sra. tambien le gusta criar gallinas y plantas, tiene muchas plantas en sus apartamentos, ella es una persona muy humilde y le tienen mucho aprecio, ya que ella atiende bien a sus inquilinos, ella tiene pensado construir y arreglar unos apartamentos que estan deteriorados, y por esto es que esta solicitando un credito
texts.en:
Rosa G. has made a living renting out apartments to help maintain herself and her widowed daughter for a long time now. She gets up very early to tidy the apartments and the backyard. She also likes to raise hens and grow plants; there is a good deal of greenery in her apartments. She is a very humble individual and her tenants hold her in high esteem, as she is attentive to their needs. She has it in mind to build and refurbish some run-down apartments, for which she is requesting a loan.

Translated from Spanish by Eleanor Stilgoe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cement, brick sand and gravel

loans.name: Tropical Group

texts.es: El banco comunal “Tropical” esta representado por el señor Abad y conformado por 14 miembros dedicados en su mayoría al comercio de abarrotes, comida, cosméticos, ropa y al servicio de transporte público de pasajeros y a la elaboración de pan. Como en todo rubro comercial siempre existe la competencia de productos de calidad es por esta razón que los miembros del grupo desean adquirí mas capital para la compra de maquinarias y herramientas para la elaboración de productos así como para la compra de insumos y materiales para su comercialización. El desarrollo que tuvieron estas familias integradas e el grupo se debe precisamente a que van ya cursando su quinto ciclo juntos demostrando tener ganas de trabajar y responsabilidad para cumplir no solo con la institución si no el compromiso que tienen con el grupo para salir adelantes y seguir progresando juntos.
texts.en:
Mr. Abad represents the communal bank “Tropical.” The group has 14 members. Most sell groceries, food, and cosmetics, or work in public transportation or bread baking. As with all commercial areas, there is always competition among quality products. This is why this group's members want to acquire more capital. They want to buy equipment and tools to make products and to buy supplies and materials for marketing their products. The development that the families that are part of this group have had is precisely because they are already on their 5th cycle demonstrating together their desire to work. And also demonstrating their responsibility in meeting their obligations, not only with the institution, but also with the commitments they have with the group to get ahead and to continue progressing together.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Capital de Operaciones

loans.name: Suraiya M. Anwar Group

texts.en:
Suraiya baji is the wife of M. A. who lives in Vehari, Pakistan. Vehari city is famous for its shrines. Her husband is a driver and drives a rented auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Her husband is a very hardworking guy but he couldn’t get all the rewards of his struggle.  This hurt Suraiya baji very much. She operates a sewing clothes business. She sews clothes without thinking about day and night and collects orders from her neighbors. She saves her income in a committee and plans to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle) with the committee amount. She is applying for a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw because she is lacking Pak Rs. 15,000 for the new rickshaw. 

She is the group leader of three other women from her locality. Rani baji wants a loan to buy wood to sell. Manzooran baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for loading. Naziran baji wants a loan to buy another juicer machine for her juice corner. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Jane's Group

texts.en: Jane K. is the leader of the Lubugumu Twekembe women's group, which has been in existence for six years. She is a hard-working and devoted lady with a business of farming matooke, cassava, sweet potatoes and so on, as well as making local brew for sale as a wholesaler and at a retail price for her customers at her bar at her home. She is happy that the loans help her on her farm with buying quality seeds as well as employing manpower, plus buying bananas and yeast used for making her brew. She is a married woman with 10 children, five of whom are still in school while the rest are doing various businesses. She needs a loan to help with paying her children’s school fees and buying bananas and yeast for making her local brew.

loans.use: School fees and buying bananas and yeast for making local brew

loans.name: Ebere

texts.en: Ebere sells foodstuffs.  She is 32 years old and is married with three children.  She is requesting a loan of N100,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell.  She says thank you.

loans.use: Purchase more foodstuffs to sell.

loans.name: Teodora

texts.es:
La señora Teodora, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Santa Ana”, Distrito de Moyobamba, Provincia Moyobamba, Departamento de San Martín. Es Casada, tiene 47 años y es madre 04 hijos, que aun dependen de ella y están estudiando.

Agradece a sus padres, por haberla apoyado en sus estudios de Cosmetodologia, ya que supo valerse de esto, para implementar su pequeño salón de belleza, ubicada en su misma casa, un local bien acondicionado, para atender a sus clientes.
Nos cuenta que hoy en día le va muy bien, ya que es conocida por sus amigos y vecinos, realiza diferentes tipos de tintes, peinados y cortes, tanto para damas, caballeros y niños.

En la actualidad ofrece en el mismo servicio  y con el préstamo de  S/1,500.00, comprará sus materiales de trabajo como: laca en frascos, tintes de cabello en diferentes colores, oxigenta, talcos, shampos y cremas de pelo.
También brinda el servicio, de manicure y pedicure y para esto comprara esmaltes en diferentes colores y detalles.

Es ella quien toma las decisiones en los gastos y ganancias de su negocio. En lo personal,  se siente una Mujer independiente, decidida y más segura, responsable con el pago de sus cuotas. Agradece a Manuela Ramos por brindarle el apoyo, para iniciarme con su actual negocio.
texts.en:
Mrs. Teodora belongs to "Banco Comunal "Santa Ana", District of Moyobamba, Province Moyobamba, Department of San Martín. She is married, 47 years old and a mother of 4 who are still dependent on her and are students.

She is grateful to her parents for having supported her in her studies of cosmetology as it enabled her to start her small beauty salon, a well-conditioned facility located at her house, where she treats her clients. She tells us that presently she is doing very well as she is well-known by friends and neighbors and she makes different kinds of dyeing, sets, and haircuts, for ladies, gentlemen, and children.

Presently she works at the same place and with the loan of S/.1,500.00 she will buy work material such as: cans of spray, different colored dye, oxigenta (peroxide solution), talcs, shampoos, and hair cream. She also gives manicure and pedicure for which she will buy nailpolish in different colors.

She herself is in charge of making the decisions on expenses and earnings regarding her business. Personally she feels independent, decided and self-confident, responsable for the repayment. She is grateful to Manuela Ramos for giving her support to set up her present business.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck Christensen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase material such as hair dye and hair cream.

loans.name: Francis

texts.en: Francis M. is married and has three children. He has received schooling through middle school. He has an MSLC (middle school leaving certificate). Francis has been selling electrical appliances in Kotokoraba in Cape Coast since 2003. His wife is a trader. Francis uses his income to pay for utility bills and other expenses. Francis will use the loan to purchase more electrical appliances and expand the business. With the new profits from his expanded business, Francis plans to pay school fees and reinvest in his business.

loans.use: Francis will use the loan to purchase more electrical appliances and expand his business.

loans.name: Philip

texts.en: Philip B. is married and has three children. He has received schooling through senior high. Philip sells provisions, assorted biscuits, and candies in Hohoe, which he has done for five years. His wife is a petty trader with a little income. Philip is solely responsible for the family financial expenses. Philip will use the loan to purchase plastic products to add to his provisions for resale. With the new profits from his expanded business, Philip plans to reinvest.

loans.use: To purchase plastic products for resale.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is a 39 year old father of five. He lives in the Mukuru slums of Nairobi and runs a food kiosk. He has requested his first loan of Ksh. 20,000 to enable him start a cereals business. He has been in this business for the last thirteen years after eight years in employment. He desires to buy a piece of land, build a home and educate his children. He describes himself as social, patient and determined.


Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing access to financial opportunities. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: Start a cereals business

loans.name: Dwene Ansa Group

texts.en: Doris is twenty-nine years old. She is married and has given birth to four children, all attending school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a town called Wiawso in the Western Region of Ghana. Wiawso is a commercial and farming town. Doris is a food vendor. She is the leader of a trust bank group called ‘Dwene ansa’, meaning reason before. The group members are engaged either in farming and/or trading activities. They sell/supply in their local market and nearby communities. They sometimes trek to nearby community markets. They want a loan to buy goods in bulk to expand their businesses.

loans.use: To buy stock.

loans.name: Maritza Bernarda

texts.es: Maritza Bernarda S. Chavarría tiene 45 años. Es una mujer muy responsable ya que tiene 3 hijos a su cargo y los mantiene ella ya que es madre soltera y sus hijos son lo más importante. Su actividad económica es una pulpería. Hace más de 15 años que se dedica a este negocio. Ella dio inicio a esta actividad en su vivienda, y poco a poco ha logrado incrementar en productos por lo que así fue incrementando clientes. A pesar de las dificultades que enfrento como es el poco apoyo 	que tenia por lo que no tenía el capital suficiente para invertir en todos los productos, pero por medio de una amiga  que le hablo de Fundación León 2000 decide empezar a realizar financiamientos y seguir con el negocio. Ahora solicita este financiamiento para capital de trabajo para la compra de café, jugos, huevos, arroz, aceite, gaseosas, pan y otras cosas. El sueño de Maritza es que sus hijos luchen para salir adelante.
texts.en:
Maritza Bernarda S. Chavarría is 45 years old. She is a very responsible woman with three children under her care, who are the most important part of her life. She takes care of the children by herself, as she is a single mother. She has worked as the proprietor of a general store for 15 years, a business she started from her home. Little by little Maritza has managed to increase her sales as her number of customers has increased. Despite the difficulties she has faced, such as the lack of support since she has not had the sufficient amount of capital to invest in all the products, Maritza wishes to keep up with her business. After a friend told her about Fundación León 2000, she decided to start to apply for loans and keep her store running. Now Maritza is asking for this loan for working capital so that she can purchase coffee, juices, eggs, rice, oil, sodas, and bread, among other things. The dream of Maritza is that her children can continue to fight to come out on top.

Translated from Spanish by Kevin Credo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital, products to stock a general store

loans.name: Beatrice's Group

texts.en:
Beatrice is the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She is 27 years old and divorced with two children, ages 8 and 4 years old, who are in primary school. She also cares for her parents. She is a hard working and determined lady who has been sold agricultural produce in Namengo for seven years. At the moment, she is able to make 70,000/= as profits a week. With this, she is grateful for her loans since they enable her to have quality produce for her inventory, hence more revenue. She is faced with a lot of competition in her business, plus the scarcity of produce during some of the bad seasons. 

Beatrice has a dream of becoming a wholesale supplier to the rest of the people in her industry as well as building rental houses for her children. She needs a loan to help recapitalize her business since this enables her pay her children’s school fees on time. This is Beatrice’s 59th loan with her lending group from Pearl Microfinance Ltd.

loans.use: Buying more agricultural produce for resale

loans.name: Roselyn

texts.en:
Roselyn M. is from the village of Kiwalan, Iligan City. She is 37 years old. Roselyn is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Roselyn runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling food products in the local community. Roselyn has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos a month from these activities.

In 2009, Roselyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Roselyn is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the second loan taken out by Roselyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Kiwalan, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Murodsho

texts.ru: Аланазаров Муродшо проживает в районе Руми. Возраст 40 лет. Женат, имеет 2 детей. Сын находится в России на заработках. Сам Муродшо болеее 14 лет занимается животноводством, он откармливает и продает скот. Кредит просит для покупки скота.
texts.en:
Murodsho A. lives in Rumy. He is forty years old. He is married and has two children. His son is in Russia working. Murodsho has been working in animal husbandry for more than fourteen years. He fattens and sells cattle. He is asking for a loan to buy cattle.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying cattle

loans.name: Celina

texts.es:
La señora Celina, pertenece al Banco Comunal “El Triunfo”, Distrito de San Hilarión, Provincia de San Martín, Departamento de San Martín. Es Conviviente, tiene 49 años y es madre de 03 hijos, 01 que aun dependen de ella y están estudiando.

La necesidad de sacar adelante a sus hijos y gracias a su espíritu y energía emprendedora que posee, ella decide iniciar su propio negocio de venta de gallinas vivas, con un capital de S/. 300.00, donde comenzó vendiendo poco a poco y haciéndose mas conocida por sus clientes, que ya conocen de la actividad que realiza.

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,500.00, comprará mas aves de corral como gallinas, pavos, patos. Parte del dinero también lo invertirá comprando alimento balanceado y vitaminas, para mantener sanos a sus animales y libres de cualquier enfermedad.

Se siente muy satisfecha con el trabajo que realiza, pese que es un trabajo duro y tiene que levantarse temprano, cree que vale el sacrificio para cumplir sus sueños y metas que tiene trazado en su vida. Así mismo agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por brindarle apoyo a ella y a  demás mujeres que quieren salir adelante.
texts.en:
Ms. Celina T. is a member of the El Triunfo Communal Bank in the San Hilarion district of the Picota province, department of San Martin. She is a 49-year-old woman with a live-in partner and 3 children, 1 of whom is her dependent and is currently in school.

Because of the need to help her children get ahead, and thanks to her enterprising spirit, she decided to launch her own chicken business with a capital of 300.00 PEN. Little by little, she has become well-known in the area.

With this 1,500.00 PEN loan, she will purchase more fowl, such as chickens, turkeys, and ducks. She will also invest some of the money in feed and vitamins to keep her animals healthy and disease-free.

She feels very satisfied with the work that she does, despite the fact that it is hard and that she has to wake up very early. However, she believes that the sacrifice is well worth it as it will help her reach her lifelong goals and dreams. She is also grateful to the Manuela Ramos Movement for supporting her and other women like her who want to get ahead in life.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase ingredients for meal preparation

loans.name: Francisca

texts.es:
La señora Francisca es socia del Banco Comunal “Lupakas” desde hace 4 años atrás, del distrito de Pilcuyo, provincia de El Collao, departamento de Puno. Ella tiene 50 años de edad, es casada y tiene 2 hijos. Estudió primaria completa y se dedica a la compra y venta de ropa.
Francisca nos cuenta que con el primer préstamo solicitado al Movimiento Manuela Ramos que fue de S/. 500.00 nuevos soles pudo aumentar su capital.
Ella solicitará un crédito de S/. 1,500.00 nuevos soles con el que podrá comprar ropa.
Su sueño para el futuro es aumentar su negocio y vivir con más comodidad.
Lo que más le gusta de su Banco Comunal es el ahorro y la puntualidad de las socias.
texts.en:
Francisca has been a member of the “Lupakas” communal bank for four years. She lives in the district of Pilcuyo in the province of El Collao, department of Puno. Francisca is 50 years old, married, and has 2 children. She completed her primary school education and makes a living selling clothing. Francisca tells us that the first loan she requested from the Manuela Ramos organization was for 500.00 soles, and she used it to increase her capital. She is now asking for a loan of 1,500.00 soles, which she will use to purchase clothing. Francisca’s dream for the future is to increase her business and to live more comfortably. Her favorite things about her communal bank are the savings and the punctuality of the other members.

Translated from Spanish by Christopher Knutson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing clothing

loans.name: Kiria

texts.es: Kiria tiene 34 años, y cuya familia esta conformada por su esposo y dos pequeños hijos y juntos viven en su casa propia. Es así que para ayudar con la manutención de sus hijos, decidió hace un año dedicarse a la venta de productos de primera necesidad, en un pequeño espacio frente a su casa, de esta manera su negocio le ha permitido dar rentas necesarias para el beneficio de su familia así como apoyar en los estudios de sus hijos. Para Kiria lo que más le agrada de su trabajo es la comunicación con las personas, eso le dio mucha ventaja por lo que ahora cuenta con gran número de clientela lo que hace que sus ventas aumenten, mediante este trabajo apoya a su esposo, quien es policía, con los gastos de la familia. Kiria planea más adelante tener un minimarket y para ello deberá trabajar muy duro. Este es su sexto préstamo con MFP y promete ser puntual en sus pagos, asimismo manifiesta que le gusta trabajar con su grupo comunal ya que todos son muy comunicativos. Ella invertirá el préstamo que solicita en la compra de productos para abastecer su tienda para que así pueda prosperar su negocio.
texts.en:
Kiria is 34 years old. Her family is made up of her husband and two small children. They live together in their own house. In order to help support her children she decided to sell general goods in a small space in front of her house a year ago. Her business has allowed her to earn some income to help her family and support her children's schooling.

Being able to communicate with people is what she likes the most about her job. This ended up being an advantage since now she has a big clientele which helps keep her sales high. Her job also helps her husband, a policeman, with the family expenses. Kiria plans to have a mini-market in the future and will have to work hard to get there.

This is her sixth loan with MFP and she vows to be on time with her payments. She says she enjoys working with the group since they are all very communicative. She will invest the loan in the purchase of inventory so that her business can prosper.

Translated from Spanish by Betyna Almeida-Covarrubias, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of inventory to supply her store

loans.name: Sarhaya

texts.en:
Sarhaya M. is 30 years old and married to a tax collector. She has two school-aged children. Sarhaya is currently in the business of selling small items such as biscuits, cakes and sweets from home, and is requesting a loan to purchase perfumes, earrings and shoes to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, Sarhaya hopes to be able to build a permanent house.

About BRAC
BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted at returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase perfumes, earrings and shoes to sell

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.es:
La señora Elizabeth es una cliente nueva que llega a la institucion por recomendación de clientes que ya trabajaron con la institucion, esta casada y tiene hijos pequeños, la señora  Elisabeth tiene su puesto en la laguna de cota cota donde vende comida (almuerzo y platos extras). La señora atiende el negocio con la ayuda de su esposo, pero la semana pasada este tuvo un viaje al exterior, la cliente necesita el dinero de este credito para la compra de mercaderia como: refrescos, garrafas, viveres y carne entre otros por que por las fiestas de carnavales la señora tiene mas ventas de platos extras( fricase y chicharron platos tipicos de la ciudad de La Paz y de Cochabamba hechos con carne de chancho).

La Sra Elisabeth es muy trabajadora y esta agradecida con Emprender y Kiva por la confianza brindada en la otorgacion del credito.
texts.en:
Elizabeth is a new client, who comes to the institution recommended by former clients of the institution. She is married and has three, small children. She has a stand at Lake Cota Cota where she sells prepared meals. Her husband usually helps her with the business but last week he had to go abroad so she needs funds to buy merchandise like soft-drinks, caraffes, groceries and meats, among others because, during Carnival, her sales of extra dishes, like chicharron and fricase (two pork-based dishes typical of the cuisines of La Paz and Cochabamba) increase. Elizabeth is very hard-working and is grateful to Emprender and Kiva for the trust they have put in her by granting the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan M. is 54 years old and a widow. She has five children, none of whom go to school. Susan is currently in the business of brewing and selling local alcoholic beverages. She is requesting a loan to stock more materials to use. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to build a shop.

About BRAC
BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted at returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more materials to use

loans.name: Charlene

texts.en: Charlene R. is from the city of Gotocan Daku, Ozamiz City. She is 29 years old. Charlene is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Charlene owns and operates a business operating motor transport services. Charlene has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month from these activities. In 2007, Charlene joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Charlene has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from GDMPC. Charlene is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to repair an existing vehicle for better service. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Charlene from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair existing vehicle for better service

loans.name: Otgonsuren

texts.en: Otgonsuren is 52 years old and lives with her husband and daughter in Arhangai province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent.  During the day, she operates a meat trading business in her home province. Otgonsuren has been operating her meat trading business and her dairy selling business since 2002, and has steadily expanded her business. At the beginning, her working capital was approximately 100,000 tugrugs (~ 70 USD), but through her hard work and determination, today Otgonsuren's working capital exceeds 2,000,000 tugrugs (~ 1407 USD). Otgonsuren has great communication skills and is a very hard working person. She is requesting a 500,000-tugrug loan to purchase a large amount of meat to sell for a profit.

loans.use: To purchase meat for her butcher shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Mom

texts.en:
