Mom P., 50, is widowed and resides with two children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for clay and ceramic products. She produces baskets for sale for an income of about USD 2 per day. Her daughter is employed at a local garment factory, earning an income of USD 3 per day to help cover the family expenses.  

P. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase a motorbike for the family use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. P. is pictured with her daughter and son-in-law here.

loans.use: buy a motorbike for the family use

loans.name: Miguel Ángel

texts.es:
Miguel Ángel C. A.   tiene 23 años, es soltero.  Viven en el recinto San Francisco de Rumí pamba a una  a una distancia de hora y media del  Cantón San Miguel Provincia de Bolívar.
El socio es un miembro de la ventanilla rural “San Francisco de Rumí pamba”.  La misma que esta conformada por 25 socios en total, los cuales la mayoría se dedican a la agricultura.
Miguel Ángel  trabaja en la agricultura toda su vida como  fuente principal económica de su familia.  Dentro de los  cultivos que más sobresalen en la zona es: maíz, papas, trigo.   Vende los productos cada cosecha en la ciudad de San Miguel. 
Miguel Ángel  solicita el crédito para comprar insumos agrícolas, abonos, fertilizantes para sus cultivos.  Su meta es mejorar la calidad del producto y mejorar su fuente de ingresos.   Los desafíos que enfrentan son llegar a vender sus productos sin intermediarios ya que ellos les explotan, ya que en tiempo de cosecha  bajan los precios de venta de los productos. Miguel Ángel  manifiesta que en sus tiempos libres acude a fiestas cívicas de su comunidad, en conjunto con sus amigos.
texts.en:
Miguel Angel C. A. is 23 years old and single. He lives in the San Francisco de Rumi Pamba precincts about an hour and a half from Canton San Miguel Provincia de Bolivar. He is a member of the San Francisco de Rumi Pamba village bank made up of 25 members who primarily work in agriculture. Miguel Angel works in agriculture as well and uses this to support himself. The primary crops grown in the area are corn, potatoes and wheat. He sells his products in the city of San Miguel. Miguel Angel is seeking a loan to buy agricultural products and fertilizers for his crops. His goal is to improved the quality of his crops to improve his income. One of his major challenges is finding a way to sell his products without using a middleman as the middlemen generally exploit the farmers by lowering their prices during harvest time. Miguel Angel says that in his free time he likes to participate in the civic activities of his community with his friends.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Agricultural products and fertilizers for his crops

loans.name: Blanca Nube

texts.es:
La señora  Blanca C. es socia del bankito Mujeres de Trabajo ubicado en la ciudad de Azogues o llamada tambien San Francisco de Peleusí de Azogues, es la  capital de la provincia del  Cañar que por su ubicación topográfica es una ciudad bien asoleada desde el punto Este en el templo del Santuario Franciscano, además podemos observar grandes inclinaciones hasta el cajón del río Burgay, mientras que en el sentido sur-norte se conforman breves planicies que permitieron el asentamiento y desarrollo del trazo urbano con las respectivas variantes y adaptaciones lo que hace que la ciudad tenga una fisonomía de gran belleza durante las horas de más sol produciendo fuertes contrastes que acentúan los valores de su distribución urbano-arquitectónica.

Nuestra socia se encuentra en su tercer ciclo trabajando con  la fundación  invitada por una amiga que ya no pertenece al bankito, ella es comerciante de billetes de lotería labora de 9 a.m. a 7 p.m.  con ésta actividad ha logrado salir  adelante con su familia.

Blanca tiene 47 años de edad, se separó de su esposo hace dos  años, fruto de su unión concibió un hijo que se encuentra de 10 años y  se encuentra estudiando en una escuela de la ciudad, no tiene casa propia por lo que vive en casa de su mamá, con sus nuevo crédito invertira en la compra de más billetes de lotería.

Su meta es comprarse un auto.
texts.en:
Blanca C. is a member of the Bankito Mujeres de Trabajo (Working Women Community Bank) located in the town of Azogues (also called San Francisco de Peleusí de Azogues), the capital city of the Cañar county. This town enjoys a lot of sunshine, thanks to its geographical position: on the eastern side, from the church of the Franciscan Sanctuary, we can in fact appreciate big slopes descending towards the bed of the Burgay river, while the south-north axis is draped by short planes that have allowed the settlement and development of the urban outline, with relevant paths and adjustments giving the town a beautiful look during daylight hours, and thus creating strong contrasts emphasizing its urban-architectural layout. Blanca is in her third cycle with the foundation: she was introduced to us by a friend that no longer belongs to the bank. She sells lottery tickets, working from 9 am to 7 pm. Through this activity she has succeeded in getting by with her family. Blanca is 47 years old and separated from her husband two years ago. They have a 10-year-old son, studying in a town school. Not having an house of her own, she lives in her mother’s house. She will use this new loan to buy more lottery tickets. Her goal is to buy a car.

Translated from Spanish by Emanuela Villa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy more lottery tickets.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en: Nancy B. sells porridge powder (cereals such as maize, groundnuts and soy beans that have been milled into a powdered form) at Takoradi.  Nancy has received junior high education.  She is married to a driver. She helps her husband in taking care of the family. Her loan will be added to her working capital to improve her business and increase her sales of the powdered cereals. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save to acquire a plot of land.

loans.use: increase her sales of the powdered cereals

loans.name: Jairo Antonio

texts.es: Jairo Mogollón Narváez, es el propietario del negocio “Súper Tiendas 3 Jotas” ubicado en la ciudad de Bogotá, la capital de Colombia, donde vive con su esposa y sus dos hijos de 14 y 24 años de edad. Su negocio es una especie de supermercado donde vende víveres, ranchos licores, drogas, aseo, artículos de miscelánea y  minutos a celulares; este negocio tiene 14 años de estar ubicado en el mismo sitio, lo que indica que se encuentra muy bien posicionado, por eso quiere seguir surgiendo con él y adicionarle una panadería y cafetería mas adelante, que es justamente su desafío. Este es su primer crédito con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo y está solicitando $2.000.000  COP, para surtirlo con abarrotes, ranchos y víveres, comprando en un mayor volumen, para que su utilidad se vea aumentada gradualmente con la venta de sus productos, que   rotan diariamente entre amas de casa y familias  que viven en el sector, especialmente en el conjunto residencial donde se encuentra ubicado y donde están sus principales compradores
texts.en:
Jairo Mogollón Narváez is the proprietor of the business “Súper Tiendas 3 Jotas” located in the city of Bogota, the capital of Colombia. He lives in Bogota with his wife and two children ages fourteen and twenty-four. His business is a type of supermarket where he sells groceries, licour, drugs, cleaning products, miscellaneous items, and cell phone minutes. This business has been in the same location for fourteen years, which indicates that he has a good location. This is why he wants to continue there and in the future add a bakery and a cafe, which is exactly what his challenge is. This is his first loan with "Fundación Mario Santo Domingo" and he is asking for $2,000.000 COP to stock his business with groceries, rations and provisions, buying them in bulk, so he can gradually see an increase in sales of his products. He sells to housewives and families who live in the area, especially in the residential area he is located in and where his main customers are.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To stock with groceries, rations, and provisions in greater volume.

loans.name: Suraiya's Group

texts.en:
Suraiya is a housewife and a great mother who plays her part very effectively. She is a citizen of a city called Borewala, in Pakistan. She owns a small house of two rooms and has been living in it with her family for over 25 years. She has given birth to two kids: one daughter and one son.
  
Her husband is involved in the animal-selling business and her son, who is 22 years old, has a bike-rental business. They both work hard to manage the financial expenses of the family. Her daughter is 15 years old and helps her manage the household chores.
 
Suraiya is applying for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband, who will buy goats for his animal-selling business. Suraiya is very hopeful about her family’s bright future. This is her fourth year to be with Asasah. She has maintained good credit behavior.

loans.use: Purchase animals for reselling

loans.name: Kashenyi Kwetungura, Kihihi Group

texts.en:
S. Benard, aged 43, has come a long way with his timber selling business. He started with the savings he got from small-scale tea growing in his home area of Kashenyi, Kihihi. Having had determination and a vision to change for the better, the married father of 7 children invested in the timber sales business. He gained confidence from his friends who were in the business and gave him the idea.


He supplies to timber dealers from the big city centers with large stores. This has seen him earn 360,000 Ugandan shillings on a monthly basis. His main intention is to expand but he is facing long odds in implementing this as he lacks capital input. With this loan, he will buy more trees for cutting timber and thus be able to generate more sales revenue to enable him to meet his family's needs.

loans.use: to buy more trees for timber cutting

loans.name: El Valle (Cuenca) Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal El Valle está formado por 9 personas entre hombres y mujeres, viven en la parroquia del Valle y la mayoría de su población se dedica a la agricultura y ganadería, su gente más joven va a la ciudad en busca de un mejor trabajo y también han migrado a otros países del mundo para ofrecerles a sus familias una estabilidad económica. Nuestras socias son personas que trabajan en diferentes actividades pero con un fin en común, que es  llevar el pan de cada día a sus hogares.

La Señora Gloria Esperanza A. vive en la comunidad de La Victoria Baja que pertenece a la parroquia del Valle, es su primer crédito y fue invitada por su hermana a formar parte de este grupo de mujeres luchadoras. Se dedica a los quehaceres domésticos de una casa en la cual labora hace 5 años, trabaja de lunes a sábado de 6 a.m. hasta las 7 p.m., también se dedica a la cría de chanchos. 
Doña Gloria es muy joven  tiene 21 años, es madre soltera de un niño de 10 meses de edad, no tiene casa propia por lo que vive en la misma casa en donde labora. El  dinero de su crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de chanchos. Su sueño es tener casa propia.

La Señora María Barbarita C. vive en la comunidad de El Paraíso que pertenece a la parroquia de El Valle, tiene 33 años, es casada y tiene 6 hijos de 17, 16, 14, 12, 5 y 1 año de edad, sus tres primeros hijos trabajan y ayudan en la economía del  hogar, su cuarto hijo pasa en casa ya que no estudia, su quinto hijo este año ingresa a la escuela, su esposo trabaja como esquibador (cargador), no tienen casa propia por lo que viven en una casa que les ha prestado un conocido.
La Señora María Barbarita trabaja como empleada domestica, labora de lunes a sábado de 8 a.m. hasta las 4 p.m., realiza esta actividad hace un mes y también se dedica a la cría de pollos. Es su tercer crédito que realiza en la fundación y le han beneficiado mucho en su hogar, su crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de alimento para sus pollos. Su sueño es  llegar a tener su casa propia.
texts.en:
The community bank El Valle is made up of 9 people, men and women. They live in the parish of Valle and most of population work in agriculture and cattle farming. The younger people go to the city in search of better jobs and also have moved to other countries in the world to offer their families economic stability. Our members are people who work in different activities but with a common purpose, which is to bring the daily bread to their homes. Mrs. Gloria Esperanza A. lives in the community La Victoria Baja, belonging to the parish of Valle. It is her first loan and she was invited by her sister to form part of this group of hardworking women. She does household chores in a house where she has worked for 5 years. She works Monday-Saturday from 6 a.m. until 7 p.m. She also raises pigs. Doña Gloria is very young she is 21 years old. She is a single mother to a 10 month old baby boy. She does not own her own home so she lives in the house she works. She is going to invest in the purchase of pigs with the money from the loan. Her dream is to have her own house. Mrs. María Barbarita C. lives in the El Paraíso community belonging to the parish of El Valle. She is 33 years old, married and has 6 children ages 17, 16, 14, 12, 5, and 1. Her three oldest children work and help around the house. Her fourth child lives at home and does not study. Her fifth child started school this year. He husband works as a loader. They do not own their own home, so they live in a house that they borrow from an acquaintance. Mrs. María Barbarita works as a domestic employee. She works Monday-Saturday from 8 a.m. until 4 p.m. She has been doing this for over a month and she also raises chickens. This is her third loan with Fundación and they have greatly benefitted her and her home. She is going to purchase food for her chickens with this loan. Her dream is to own her own home.

Translated from Spanish by Dina Bach, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy pigs and food for chickens

loans.name: Djoubo Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité DJUBOO est a vu le jour il y a de cela environs 09 ans. Il est composé de 09 femmes qui sont toutes issues du même quartier. Elles ont formé leur groupe par affinité et par voisinage. Le groupe fait partie du Banc Villageois de KADIOR.

Madame ROKHAYATOU S. assise à gauche sur la photo est responsable du groupe de solidarité. Elle est de 52 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 6 enfants en charge.

Elle fait de la transformation et vente de savon artisanal. Elle fait la transformation à base d'huile de de fruits sauvages (appelé YEME) récolté dans la forêt. 

Avec son nouveau crédit elle va acheter plusieurs fûts d'huile de "YEME" afin d'augmenter sa production. 

Son objectif est de soutenir son mari dans la prise en charge de la famille.
texts.en:
The solidarity group DJUBOO was created about nine years ago. It is composed of nine women who are all from the same district. They formed their group according to their affinities and neighborhoods. The group is part of the Banc Villageois of KADIOR. Ms. ROKHAYATOU S. (seated at the left in the photo) is the leader of the solidarity group. She is 52 years old, married, and the mother of six children to support. She makes and sells artisanal soaps. Her process involves the oil of wild fruit (called yeme) harvested in the forest. With her new loan, she is going to buy several drums of yeme oil in order to increase her production. Her goal in supporting her husband is to support the family.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Developing and advancing her business

loans.name: Belen

texts.en:
This is Belen S., 45, resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Nelson S. and mother to a young adult who is already working and helping her with the household finances, and her youngest, who is currently enrolled in college this year. By the grace of God, Belen has managed to support her children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Belen operates a school supplies store where she also sells Fern-C, a Vitamin C supplement. Her customers comprise of students, both elementary and high school, and parents, mostly mothers, who buy her health supplements for their children. She earns to at least Ph200-300 sales every day.

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a Php15,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like paper, pens, folders, and other school materials to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
  
Belen dreams of being able to renovate her house soon, with all of her work with the business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more quantities of products like paper, pens, folders, and other school materials to expand her product inventory.

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet P., from the village of Poblacion, Mahinog, Camiguin Province, is 53 years old, married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Juliet owns and operates a specialized retail store that buys, sells and rents digital video disc products in the local community. Engaged in her business for over 13 years, she earns approximately 8000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Juliet joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting her first loan of 5000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell, she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her enterprise.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn M. L. is forty-two years old and married. Her husband is a mason and they have five children aged between twenty-one years old and five years old. Her business is located at Mariakani market in Mombasa, Kenya. Mombasa is the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many many tourist attractions not, forgetting the Indian Ocean's white beaches. 

Evelyn has been providing tailoring services for the last fifteen years to the local people and has two employees. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is creditors who don't pay their debts at all and don't even come to pick the clothes made as per their request. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. 

She is using her loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more materials to meet the customer demand. She hopes to grow her business and build her own premises where she will be running her business. She sees herself being able to export clothes in future. She describes herself as sociable and God-fearing.

loans.use: Materials

loans.name: Juan Manuel

texts.es: El señor Juan Manuel J. O. es trabajador de la Alcaldia de Chinandega donde tenemos un Convenio con cuotas deducibles de salaries quincenalmente, se desempeña en le area de Auditor Fiscal, tiene 5 años de trabajar en la Alcaldia y lleva 03 años de trabajar con CEPRODEL y ha obtenido 05 credito, es casado su esposa trabaja tambien en la Alcaldia de Chinandega tienen 01 hijo en edad escolar y ambos han logrado independisar su familia, esta vez solicito credito para cubrir unos gastos de medicamentos, ya que no le cubria el seguro social.
texts.en:
Juan Manuel J. O. works for the Alcaldia de Chinandega (Chinandega City council), which has an agreement in place with CEPRODEL whereby forthnightly repayments come straight from the salaries paid. 

Juan Manuel works as a tax consultant. He has worked for the council for 5 years. In his 3 years with CEPRODEL he has obtained 5 loans. He is married and his wife also works for the Chinandega council. They have a son of school age. They have managed to make their family financially independent. He requests a loan to pay for medicines not covered by the social insurance.

loans.use: Buy medicines.

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert is thirty years old and married to Penninah. He has two children and supports three other relatives. He has a retail shop where he sells cornmeal, wheat flour, soap and detergent. He has been in the business for eight months with an income of 25,000 KES a month.

This is his second loan with KADET and he plans to add more stocks of sugar, flour, soap and detergent to his shop. He has never borrowed from another MFI. 

He hopes to expand his business and be sustainable.

loans.use: To buy stocks of sugar, flour, soap and detergent.
